author: Simon Harris
title: London's cabbies dealt huge blow as judge backs app used by Uber
text:
London's famous cabbies were dealt a huge blow today when a High Court judge backed the revolutionary minicab app used by Uber.
Credit: PA The judge ruled the app is not a 'taximeter' and does not break the law.
The test case was brought by Transport for London after months of angry protests by cab drivers.
Credit: Reuters The arrival of the Uber brand in London has seen the number of minicabs rocket. There are almost 30 times as many as there were three years ago.
In September 2012, TfL recorded a daily average of 448 private hire vehicles in central London. In August this year it was 13,151.
Disruptive technology and new business models have radically changed the way that taxi and private hire services operate and has widened customer choice.
This is welcome.
At the same time, as the regulator, we must ensure that regulatory requirements are met and are developed in a way that delivers the high standards customers deserve.
As part of this, we are gauging public opinion on a range of potential changes to private hire regulations, including stricter rules on insurance and English language skills.
We know that some ideas put forward for consultation are controversial, which is why we want as many people as possible to tell us what they think to help shape the future of private hire in London.
– Leon Daniels, TfL’s Managing Director of Surface Transport Despite today's ruling TfL is considering new rules which could restrict Uber drivers and their passengers .
A statutory five minute wait between a car being ordered and the passenger being picked up is one proposal in a public consultation.
The move is seen as a way of stopping Uber drivers parking 'taxi rank style' in busy areas like the West End, waiting for customers to click their app.
Last updated Fri 16 Oct
